subject: Example phrases using keyboard mapping proposals
msgSnippet: Here are a few phrases (due, in order, to: Jefferson et al., Shaw, Seuss, Wolfe and Pasternak) to illustrate some of the choices we are considering with the
messageBody:
Here are a few phrases (due, in order, to: Jefferson et al., Shaw,
Seuss, Wolfe and Pasternak) to illustrate some of the choices we are
considering with the various keyboard mapping proposals:

When in the course of human events...
The rain in Spain falls mainly on the plain.
He likes to wink and drink pink ink.
The astronauts were flying and drinking, and drinking and driving.
Zhivago's vision was obscured by snow.

Note in the representations below that N is clearly best for both #21
and alternate #23. Since #23 and alternate #23 are both very commonly
used QS letters, I favor using N for alternate #23. It does take some
effort to get used to seeing G for #21, especially in words ending in
'ink'. But it also takes effort to get used to seeing M for alternate
#23. Either choice has a drawback.

The last example illustrates the choice of J or Z for #14. I find
either one reasonable.

(Aside: how does everyone like using #21 instead of #26+#21 to
represent "-ing"? I find it a bit unsettling in a word such as
"flying" where no consonant separates the syllables.)

Here are the phrases in each mapping:

Jerome kbd:
{weG iG H kYrs v hjMman iveGts...
H rEG iG /spEG fYlz mEGlI oG H plEG.
hI lFks t wiNk n driNk piNk iNk.
H AstranYts war flFN n driNkN, n driNkN n drFvN.
ZivygO'z viZan waz abskjard bF snO.}

QS-SAMPA:
{wEq Iq D kOrs v hjumyn IvEqts...
D req Iq `speq fOlz meqli Qq D pleq.
hi lYks t wINk n drINk pINk INk.
D astrynOts wyr flYN n drINkN, n drINkN n drYvN.
ZIvAgo'z vIZyn wyz ybskjyrd bY sno.}

Peter Guinness:
{weM iM D kQrs v hyUmun iveMts...
D rAM iM `spAM fQlz mAMlE oM D plAM.
hE lIks t wiNk n driNk piNk iNk.
D astrunQts wur flIN n driNkN, n driNkN n drIvN.
ZivRgO'z viZun wuz ubskyurd bI snO.}

BPJ2:
{weN iN D kQrs v hyUmun iveNts...
D rEN iN `spEN fQlz mENlI oN D plEN.
hI lYks t wiGk n driGk piGk iGk.
D astrunQts wur flYG n driGkG, n driGkG n drYvG.
JivAgO'z viJun wuz ubskyurd bY snO.}

QS-Nu:
{weN iN D kqrs V hyUmun iVeNts...
D rEN iN `spEN fqlz mENlI oN D plEN.
hI lYks t wiGk n driGk piGk iGk.
D astrunqts wur flYG n driGkG, n driGkG n drYVG.
JiVAgO'z ViJun wuz ubskyurd bY snO.}

Moira:
{weM iM D kyrs v hYUmun iveMts...
D rAM iM `spAM fylz mAMlE oM D plAM.
hE lIks t wiNk n driNk piNk iNk.
D astrunyts wur flIN n driNkN, n driNkN n drIvN.
JivPgO'z viJun wuz ubskYurd bI snO.}

Ted

Here are a few phrases (due, in order, to: Jefferson et al., Shaw,
Seuss, Wolfe and Pasternak) to illustrate some of the choices we are
considering with the various keyboard mapping proposals:

When in the course of human events...
The rain in Spain falls mainly on the plain.
He likes to wink and drink pink ink.
The astronauts were flying and drinking, and drinking and driving.
Zhivago's vision was obscured by snow.

Note in the representations below that N is clearly best for both #21
and alternate #23. Since #23 and alternate #23 are both very commonly
used QS letters, I favor using N for alternate #23. It does take some
effort to get used to seeing G for #21, especially in words ending in
'ink'. But it also takes effort to get used to seeing M for alternate
#23. Either choice has a drawback.

The last example illustrates the choice of J or Z for #14. I find
either one reasonable.

(Aside: how does everyone like using #21 instead of #26+#21 to
represent "-ing"? I find it a bit unsettling in a word such as
"flying" where no consonant separates the syllables.)

Here are the phrases in each mapping:

Jerome kbd:
{weG iG H kYrs v hjMman iveGts...
H rEG iG /spEG fYlz mEGlI oG H plEG.
hI lFks t wiNk n driNk piNk iNk.
H AstranYts war flFN n driNkN, n driNkN n drFvN.
ZivygO'z viZan waz abskjard bF snO.}

hE lIks t wiNk n driNk piNk iNk.
